instances.text: FNH_V 482-201 - Dietetics Practice Education Placement III
FNH_V 490-001 - Advanced Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
FNH 490 section 001 is now offered as FNH 401 section 001, "Novel Plant and Cell-based Foods."

In this course, you will examine meat, fish, egg, and dairy analogues made using plants, recombinant proteins, and cell tissue culture, from the molecular to the macroscopic level. Relation of molecular details to physical and sensory properties. Health and sustainability impacts.

Please register in FNH 401 section 001 if you are interested.

instances.text: FNH_V 497-A_101 - Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health (A)

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: To register for this course, students need to first secure a faculty supervisor and work with them to develop a project description and learning outcomes. This should be done well ahead of the terms commencement. Once these steps are completed, students can proceed to submit a course registration form to the course coordinator (fnh.dsat@ubc.ca) for approval.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Credits will be granted for only one of FNIS 400 or FNSP 400. For more information, please contact cis.program@ubc.ca. This is the lecture section of the course. Please note that both a lecture section and tutorial section are required for the course.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Credits will be granted for only one of FNIS 400 or FNSP 400. For more information, please contact cis.program@ubc.ca. This is the discussion section of the course. Please note that both a lecture section and tutorial section are required for the course.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Students will contextualize and comparatively analyze Indigenous new media from 1990 to the present moment. New media is loosely defined as digital, interactive and/or networkable content that involves user feedback and creative interaction, such as net and video art, video games, Geographic Information Systems (GIS), interactive installation, podcasts and stereoscopic photography. Focus will be on Internet art and curation, interactive websites and audio maps. Students will develop and put into practice a set of skills for analyzing, comparing, researching and writing about Indigenous new media and produce a collection of digital stories. If you have any questions, feel free to email Dr. David Gaertner at david.gaertner@ubc.ca. Credits will be granted for only one of FNSP 401F, FNSP 45&&~ ~ 4 or FNIS 454. This section is intended for undergraduate students only. If you are a graduate student, please visit: http://fnis.arts.ubc.ca/graduate-courses/ regarding the registration process. If the course is full, please register in the waitlist section. Email cis.program@ubc.ca with any questions.

instances.text: FREN_V 416-101 - Contemporary French Literature and Culture

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Shades of Truth and Fiction in Contemporary French Literature: This course explores how a variety of contemporary French authors interprets historical reconstitution, gaslighting, confession, verisimilitude, autofiction, and more.  
View full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/fren416/  

Language of instruction: French

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
An introduction to the extensive and diverse production of Francophone cinema outside France (Belgium, North Africa, Lebanon, Senegal, Caribbean, Indian Ocean, Québec, etc.).  
View full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/fren428/  

Language of instruction: French

instances.text: FREN_V 495-101 - Research Seminar in French Literature and Culture

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
By reading the Ancien Régime, examine debates regarding the concepts of masculinity and femininity, which are linked to questions of identity, including constructions of linguistic, regional or national identities.  Cross-listed with FREN 502. 
View full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/fren502/

instances.text: FRE_V 490-001 - Current Issues in Food and Resource Economics

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Students must register for all of LECTURE and LABORATORY to complete registration for the course. The laboratory section is a placeholder: there is no meeting time and no room assigned. 

Impact Evaluation Analytics: This course is designed to introduce students to the principles and applications of project monitoring & evaluation (M&E). The world of international development faces many challenges, one of which is the failure of assistance interventions (aid projects and programmes). Students will develop a practical understanding of the logical processes by which projects are designed and implemented, including the need for external evaluation in order to assess the efficacy, outcomes, and sustainability of these interventions. Lack of project success, more often than not, is a result of inadequate impact evaluation strategies. Students will learn skills to develop strong monitoring & evaluation plans in order to overcome these deficiencies.

If you meet the requirements for the course/waitlist but are not able to self-register, please fill out this 2024 Winter Session Registration Request for LFS Courses form. An LFS Academic Advisor will assess your eligibility for registration and you will be notified accordingly.
